info.title: Ubidots API
info.description:
Welcome to Ubidots REST API documentation.
 Ubidots REST API allows for programmatic access to your account resources, including devices, variables, values and more.

 To interact with Ubidots REST API, we recommend using an HTTPS client. Here are a few options:

 * [Insomnia](https://insomnia.rest/): Simple yet powerful REST API Client with cookie management, environment variables, code generation, and authentication for Mac, Windows, and Linux.
 * [Postman](https://www.getpostman.com/): Powerful, simple-to-use GUI that makes API development faster, easier, and better. Comes with API request history, collections, environments, tests, sharing and more.
 * [cURL](https://curl.haxx.se/): Command line HTTP client with an intuitive UI, JSON support, syntax highlighting, wget-like downloads, plugins, and more.
 * [HTTPie](https://httpie.org/): Command line tool for transferring data using various protocols with URL syntax.

 ## API URLs

API access can be made over _HTTP_ or _HTTPS_, using the following endpoints based on your Ubidots Account type.

 **Security Note**: We strongly advise using HTTPS to make sure your data travels encrypted, and avoid exposing your API token and/or sensor data.

 ### HTTP

 Ubidots Account | Endpoint | Port
 ---|--- | --- 
 Educational | `http://things.ubidots.com` | 80
 Industrial | `http://industrial.api.ubidots.com` | 80

 ### HTTPS

 Ubidots Account | Endpoint | Port
 ---|--- | --- 
 Educational | `https://things.ubidots.com` | 443
 Industrial | `https://industrial.api.ubidots.com` | 443

 You can download the Ubidots PEM certificate for TLS [here](https://z.cdn.ubidots.com/ustatic/certs/roots.pem).

post.description:
This creates an authentication token that will expire after 6 hours.
The token can be used to authenticate every API request during this time.

The HTTP header `x-ubidots-apikey` is needed.

get.description: This endpoint lists all the user’s existing datasources.

parameters.name: ordering
parameters.description: Which field to use when ordering the results. Options are: `name` and `created_at`

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: A page number within the paginated result set.

parameters.name: page_size
parameters.description: Number of results to return per page.

next.description: Next items in the paginated sequence.

previous.description: Previous items in the paginated sequence.

post.description:
This endpoint creates a new datasource.

A datasource has a number of variables and a context where the properties are stored.
For example, a datasource called “Delivery Truck” may have the following properties:
`{“City”:”Boston”}` or `{“Type”:”Truck”}`.

Properties are not meant to change dynamically over time;
they are metadata that help you describe your datasource (device).

get.description:
This endpoint obtains an existing datasource and its details.

It also returns additional fields not required during the creation of the datasource:
`number_of_variables`: Shows the number of variables contained by the datasource.
`last_activity`: Returns the date of last activity.

put.description: This endpoint updates a datasource, you need to provide all the required fields.

patch.description: This endpoint partially updates a datasource, allowing for individual field updates.

delete.description:
This endpoint deletes a given datasource, specified by its ID.

> Please note that __deleting__ an item will erase all objects related to it, such as variables, values, events and widgets.

get.description: This endpoint lists the variables of a specified datasource, showing all variable fields.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: A page number within the paginated result set.

parameters.name: page_size
parameters.description: Number of results to return per page.

parameters.name: tag
parameters.description: Filter results to variables containing the specified tags (you can use one or more filters). Example:`?tag=weather&tag=sky`

next.description: Next items in the paginated sequence.

previous.description: Previous items in the paginated sequence.

post.description: This endpoint creates a new variable within the specified datasource.

get.description: This endpoint lists all of a user’s existing devices by label.

post.description: This endpoint receives devices variables values.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: Apply type to device on creation. Example:`?type=me_type_name`

get.description: This endpoint obtains an existing device variable and its details.

patch.description: This endpoint partially updates a variable, allowing for individual field updates.

delete.description:
This endpoint deletes a given variable.

> Please note that __deleting__ an item will erase all objects related to it, such as variables, values, events and widgets.

get.description: This endpoint reads the last value of a variable.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: A page number within the paginated result set.

parameters.name: page_size
parameters.description: Number of results to return per page.

get.description: This endpoint lists the values of a variable.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: A page number within the paginated result set.

parameters.name: page_size
parameters.description: Number of results to return per page.

parameters.name: start
parameters.description: Initial timestamp in milliseconds for values of the variable (inclusive). Example:`?end=1451570441000`

parameters.name: end
parameters.description: Final timestamp in milliseconds for values of the variable (inclusive). Example:`?end=1451570441000`

parameters.name: format
parameters.description: Specifies the format of the returned values, Options are `csv` and `json`: Example:`?format=csv`

next.description: Next items in the paginated sequence.

previous.description: Previous items in the paginated sequence.

post.description: This endpoint creates values for a variable.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: A page number within the paginated result set.

parameters.name: page_size
parameters.description: Number of results to return per page.

get.description: This endpoint lists all variables owned by a user.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: A page number within the paginated result set.

parameters.name: page_size
parameters.description: Number of results to return per page.

next.description: Next items in the paginated sequence.

previous.description: Previous items in the paginated sequence.

get.description:
This endpoint returns a variable and its details.
It shows additional fields than those required during the variable’s creation.

delete.description:
This endpoint deletes a given variable, specified by its ID.

> Please note that __deleting__ an item will erase all objects related to it, such as variables, values, events and widgets.

get.description:
This endpoint allows statistics to be computed over a temporal subset of a variable’s values.
The subset is given by the values between [start, end].

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Variable identifier

parameters.name: start
parameters.description: Initial timestamp in milliseconds for values of the variable (inclusive). Example:`?end=1451570441000`

parameters.name: end
parameters.description: Final timestamp in milliseconds for values of the variable (inclusive). Example:`?end=1451570441000`

parameters.name: aggregation
parameters.description:
A comma seperated value list of statistical figures to be computed.  
Supported figures are: `mean`, `variance`, `min`, `max`, `count`, `sum`

application/json.detail: The operation is too large to compute in a reasonable time.

get.description:
This endpoint returns the values of the specified variable.

Every value will be timestamped with a value in milliseconds according to the POSIX standard.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: A page number within the paginated result set.

parameters.name: page_size
parameters.description: Number of results to return per page.

parameters.name: start
parameters.description: Initial timestamp in milliseconds for values of the variable (inclusive). Example:`?end=1451570441000`

parameters.name: end
parameters.description: Final timestamp in milliseconds for values of the variable (inclusive). Example:`?end=1451570441000`

parameters.name: format
parameters.description: Specifies the format of the returned values, Options are `csv` and `json`: Example:`?format=csv`

next.description: Next items in the paginated sequence.

previous.description: Previous items in the paginated sequence.

post.description:
This endpoint creates a new value within the specified variable.

Every value has a timestamp that can either be specified manually by the device, or automatically by the server.

delete.description:
This endpoint allows you to delete values between specified start and end times.

> Please note that __deleting__ an item will erase all objects related to it, such as variables, values, events and widgets.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Variable identifier

parameters.name: start
parameters.description: Initial timestamp in milliseconds for values of the variable (inclusive). Example:`?end=1451570441000`

parameters.name: end
parameters.description: Final timestamp in milliseconds for values of the variable (inclusive). Example:`?end=1451570441000`

tags.name: Token
tags.description:
Every request requires a _token_. A token is a unique key that authorizes your device to ingest data inside your Ubidots account.

Tokens valid for 6 hours can be generated using your account’s _API Key_.

There are two ways to send a token in a request:

1. Send the token as an endpoint parameter, setting it with the `?token=expression`. This is the easiest but least secure method of sending authentication credentials.

2. Send the token as a request header. For this, use the `X-Auth-Token` header.

**Security Note**: While sending your token as a URL parameter can be comfortably done with many devices,
we only advise doing so in prototyping stages.
For production stages, we strongly advise sending the token using the `X-Auth-Token` header.

tags.name: Datasources
tags.description:
A datasource is equivalent to an Ubidots device.
The only difference is that `datasources` are identified using unique hash IDs,
while `devices` are identified using human-friendly, user-defined and editable API labels.
